FreeResponse: It feels like the director's idea will help improve these procedures in the future. I think it's worth it to improve the safety of the treatments in the long run.
I think because both doctors will have access to the information it is appropriate to test which method works better.  There doesn't seem to be any actual risk involved.
I think seeing which one is more effective might help, and if they are both effective, ensuring that both policies are enacted is fine.

If the doctor is performing a treatment, he or she will not be able to check the badge for accuracy. The step will only contaminate the procedure and whatever else.It doesn't make sense if to have the steps on the doctor while he or she is performing the treatment.
It will help doctors when they are doing the procedure.
There is nothing wrong with having as many precautions as possible. Having a reminder may help prevent a tragedy.
Nothing wrong with trying 2 different approaches to see which works better. Its the best way to figure out whats working
I think it would help to remember all the protocol to prevent infection, but it doesn't 100% mean infection will not occur.
A trained doctor should know already the precautionary measures when aplicating such a medical procedure.

The decision seems more beneficial than not having any posters with directions. However, it seems that more training would be needed instead of just a poster on the wall with instructions on how to prevent infections. Especially since it is such a high risk action.

It's unlikely a doctor is going to notice his or her own ID badge when operating (if, indeed, they even wear one on their outer clothing while performing surgery).  The badge would be one more item to sterilize, or more to the point, forget to sterilize.
I think it would keep the precautions present in people's mind.  It would be a constant reminder which is good.
I have no opinion because I'm not the one with the medical degree.

The director's heart is in the right place as he wants to reduce the number of infections. My only concern is that the doctor's will be distracted by the posters or take offense to their presence as an insult to their professionalism.
He's subjecting innocent patients to new methods without their consent.

The director's decision involves research with human subjects that doesn't obtain informed consent and therefore is inappropriate. (This study also didn't obtain informed consent, by the way.) However, I chose "Somewhat inappropriate" instead of "Very inappropriate" because the manipulation the director wants to use doesn't pose any additional risks to the patients other than the risks they will already be facing from the procedure. Instead, the manipulation only involves potential benefits (assuming that currently the procedure is done without any reminders of the safety steps -- incidentally, it would be a more controlled study if one group were treated exactly according to the status quo, i.e. no safety reminders, instead of both groups involving an experimental manipulation).
The director thinks that these posters might help doctors remember all of the safety steps they were trained to take during the procedure.
If the hospital director thinks the ID badge provides better precautions, then he/she should require that instead of having a control group with the precautions hanging on the wall.
This in not invasive in any way.  The list could potentially help a doctor to remember all the steps and thus prevent an infection from happening.

I feel it is somewhat appropriate, depending upon how frequently the doctor performs this procedure.  If it is important to remember (and perform) all of the steps, then it is appropriate to have them clearly listed (and have that list accessible.)  Although some patients might feel uneasy if their doctor is referencing a "cheat sheet" on their badge, I believe most would prefer that safety (infection prevention) is maximized.
helps remember
I would think a doctor should know the steps instead of having to check his/her badge or a poster.

The decision wouldn't risk the lives/wellness of any patients. He wouldn't be altering the procedures, he would be adding reminders on how to appropriately complete the procedure. Therefore, it would be very appropriate for him to do this.
He is trying to prevent errors.
I don't believe this would help in any way. The doctors already know what procedures to follow and success rate is probably a matter of skill.
It can help to remind the Doctor. However, it might scare the patient but the benefit outweigh the costs.
If the doctor is capable, he should not need these reminders of a badge and posters. If I saw him looking at either one, I would not trust him. I would think that he does not know what he is doing.
It provides an easy to remember visual aid for this procedure. It may lower infections.
Neither the badge nor the poster is likely to affect the doctor's performance. They already know these tips.

There are pros and cons; I agree with the director's reasoning that it will help doctors remember, but on the other hand doctors may feel insulted that the director feels that they can't remember the basics of their job. There is also no evidence presented that the infections are caused by doctors forgetting standard safety precautions.

I would like to think that my doctor doesn't need a poster on the wall, or something printed on a badge, to remember proper safety procedures.  There is also no guarantee that they would even READ either the badge or the poster.
I think they only need to reference this when they are doing the procedure. Having the info on the equipment used to do the procedure would seem more appropriate
if it will help save lives in the long run, then there is nothing wrong with the decision.
Posting rules and not discussing them or teaching them may not be very effective.
Its good hes trying to reduce infections. Hes just trying to save lives.
I don't see why it would be inappropriate. The precautions are present in both situations, so it seems fine to me.
In a way they probably should, but i think it should be memorized

The decision is appropriate because it highlights the procedures necessary to reduce infection. Having doctors constantly viewing it during a surgery ensures that they don't have a misstep that could lead to the infection that could be deadly.
I think this is a possible technique. Subconsciously the doctors will notice the posters and will be more likely to commit this information to memory.
It is nice to have a reminder, but I suspect that the doctors will be preoccupied with what they are doing and not even notice the posters when they are in the midst of a procedure.
It's only going to help doctor's and maybe save lives. It's a good thing to have.
Either way the groups should be treated using the safety precautions
Any time that something can reduce the number of infections that people get in the hospital and especially during surgery, it is a good thing. Even if only one person is spared infection.
Less chance of infection so why not
I think that he could increase the time frame if the infection could be deadly, they should be figuring something out sooner then a year
It think that which ever one is implemented should be used. Or both used at the same time.
I don't think that a doctor should have to be reminded of safety precautions on their badge. It seems like it would be more of a distraction.

I feel that this experiment does not pose any risk to the patients that they were not already exposed to before during treatment. The experiment seems like standard workplace safety policy change procedure.
It will allow people not to rely on memory for safety procedures which could save lives
It makes doctors aware of safety. But the patient has to be comfortable allowing this. On the other hand, doctors should already know how to take safety precautions.
It helps them remember incase something goes wrong. A good refresher.
they shouldn't make unsuspecting guniea pigs out of patients
I think its great to remind someone of things they should do so they dont end up killing someone because they forgot a simple procedure.
I think it's a little ridiculous and that in itself is an inappropriate waste of effort and time for everyones part.  I don't think it would do anything but annoy people in the transition.
I think this poster needs to be committed to memory. I dont want a doctor p[erforming a procedure on me to have to keep taking his eyes away from what he is doing.

This seems a reasonable way to determine which method of reinforcing the ideas to reduce infection is better. Both of the methods (name tag and poster on the wall) seems like it might work, though I would guess that the poster will turn out better.

Assuming the procedure itself is safe and effective, it is reasonable to test a hypothesis that presenting the safety information in a variety of ways would affect outcomes. One might assume that the poster, being more prominent, would lead to a more safe procedure. However, having to put the badge on daily may lead to more presence of mind.
It seems reasonable to have a reminder of all the necessary protocols
Not a randomized trial. But a good start to reducing or attempting to reduce infections.
I think it is good that these doctors will have consistent reminders of procedures to follow where they can see them often.
The doctors should know these precautions regardless.  The added reminders regardless of form is beneficial.
It will not hurt to have that batch, and hopefully it will remind doctors to follow procedures.
It is a good idea for doctor to have instructions available at all time. So they can just look at it quickly while performing procedure.
I think it is a good idea to implement some standard protocol for helping doctors maintain safety steps.  I think trying different methods will ensure the best method will be used.
if this is a procedure that needs to be used then it must be used

I do not believe having the list in front of them will help while performing the procedure.  I am sure the doctors can easily memorize the steps.  There are other ways to ensure the doctors follow protocol such as additional training.
I think this would be a fine idea just to keep everyones mind fresh and give them a heads up when working and to be safe while doing so.
While the intention was good and any harm seems likely to be small, it is not really a hospital director's place to run an experiment involving his patients without there consent.
I feel that if the doctors are sanitary that that stops the infection problem.
They should already know how to do it, I am indifferent to whether or not they have instructions.
I think this is appropriate because that way they should not make a mistake and it should be way less deadly infections popping up.

It's a scary thought that doctors need a set of directions to refer to before a risky treatment like this. But if it is necessary to remind doctors of precautions they need to take, it is a good idea to find out which method is the best reminder. So I decided the director came up with two good solutions, so why not test which is the best?
I would hope a doctor would know the proper procedure without having to look at a poster on a wall.
. The director thinks that these new badges might help doctors remember all of the safety steps they were trained to take during the procedure.
Its seems like a good idea to have some with ID badges with the rules helps in a pinch.
This is sensible and practical. It seems small but it might be able to save lives.
THere is nothing wrong with this per se. I don't think it will help very much, but it is certainly not inappropriate.
It is a simple idea, non-intrusive, and mitigates the risk of the procedure by making sure it is done safely.

It sounds like both types of doctors have been trained in the procedure, so the director is trying to come up with the best way to prevent infection. The director has good intentions- he wants to save lives.
These two ideas are still not enough to ensure doctors follow standard safety precautions
I think it is always a good idea to leave reminders for people. People who are very busy and juggle much information in their heads can really benefit from a visual cue.

I think that this is very appropriate.  None of us is perfect, and we all forget things at time.  This decision has the potential to reduce infections due to a doctor forgetting a certain safety precaution.
This sounds like a step in the right direction offering more training/instructions to the doctors performing the procedure so that is why I think it is appropriate.
Both groups of doctors had access to the same information.

I think it is very appropriate because it ensures that the doctors will always know the best procedures to reduce the risk of infections. The patients would also be assured that the doctors are doing everything the right way.
I think that it is harmless and could potentially help
It takes patient safety to the next level. It helps improve chances the doctors will not make a mistake during the procedures.

On one hand it could be reassuring to the patients who are having this procedure performed on them. however, one would also think that doctors were trained sufficiently and professional enough that such a basic reminder would not be necessary to post but is an automatic part of their job.
if he feels one way is safer, then he should have everyone do it the same way.

I consider it appropriate because its not a experiment that is withholding medication or altering the way medicine is being administered to the patients that need it. It is simply a way to help doctors remember all the steps in a procedure, just like a reminder.

I think it is a good way to test the two ideas. I think one year is enough time to see which method works. However the methods are not equal . One method requires no effort from the doctor (poster) the other method requires the doctor to remember to wear the badge and remember to look at the badge before treating a patient .
It is good to see which one will work better. Personally I feel a badge that is apart of someone would be easier for a person to look at. A poster is easily ignored.
Humans are by nature forgetful, or neglectful at times. Regular reminders such as the proposed poster could help reduce surgical errors.
It is very appropriate to increase patient safety.
Based on the experiments, the results is what matters and the director need time to make a decision that's why it's appropriate.

The director's decision is not likely to harm anything but it's also improbable to be helpful either. The act of touching the ID card during insertion of the tube, to consult the safety steps, is just inviting more germs into the scenario.
The badge is likely the property of the hospital. If the director thinks putting this on the badge will help the doctors, it is his decision.
I think when implementing something new it would be helpful to have something visual to reference easily.
taking extra precautions and extra directions would be very helpful to eliminate mistakes
I think it could go both ways here
It seems that this would be a fairly standard practice; such as a placebo effect that is also used when testing new medications
I think it is a good idea. It will help doctors cut down on infections.

I think that the doctors performing this procedure should not have to rely on a badge or poster at all. They should receive training that is so intense that the steps are ingrained in them. The steps should come as second nature to any doctor that is consider "fit" to perform this surgery.
It seems like a good idea for them to have the instructions right there with them. But is it really practical to have them reading directions while performing a procedure.
It is important for doctor's to take all necessary precautions for the safety of their patients.  Having the sign will give them no excuse to not be safe.
I mean there's no way to find out if this really works if we don't try. I think it is appropriate.
Everyone needs to be reminded of safety precautions, even doctors. These would be good practices.
Doctors know how to perform the procedure.  As a patient, I would feel more uneasy if my doctor had to look at steps on a poster to perform a procedure on me.
I do not see how a badge or poster would help prevent infections, unless it is doctor negligence causing these infections.
It is a good idea that wouldn't cost a pot of money to implement
I like the thought of it. But this might allow some doctors to rely on the badges with instructions, rather than knowing the skill.
Doctors are only human and many times put in a lot of hours and a direct reminder like the posters is a fantastic idea. It can only help the situation.
I feel like this is just something that wont help. Putting the posters up wont do much if the doctor legitimately doesn't know what he's doing, in the first place.
I guess it is a good way to find out what works for the future.
This is a good idea, but there should also be other procedures in place to make sure the doctors are following protocol.
Seems like not everyone is getting the same

A poster has the possibility of being a distraction in the middle of a procedure, yet if appropriately studied beforehand, it should be pretty effective. It's just a lot better than no action taken at all.
Sometimes in high pressure, high-stress situations a written reminder can help ease your mind and trigger memory.
I think the doctors know more about ths stuff than a director.  Godd intentions but meddlesome.

The experiment really should not be run on current patients without their consent.  But since he is the director he can most like do what he wants, unless there is something in the by laws which says he cannot do this.  If I was a patient, and I was randomly selected to be put in an experiment without my knowledge, I wouldn't be so happy.
If the procedure is not safe enough or memorable enough to complete by the doctor, then I do not think they should perform it at all.
Because its a good thing to have a reminder of safety precautions. When it comes to safety there is always enough room for little reminders.
If you are following a checklist procedure is will reduce mistakes that could be made.
The procedure can be dangerous so the idea is to have the most effective mode of communication for both patients and doctors. After  year the one that is best will be used all the time.
It's an everyday reminder on what to do. The doctor is more then likely to see the reminder. Sometimes things can be forgotten and I can see where this could help. At least it couldn't hurt.

I don't think its right that he's running an experiment to see which practice works better.  All safety precautions they can think of should be implemented in hopes of saving the most patients.  Both the posters and the badges should be in each room and given to each doctor.
It's like having the sign for "handwashing 30 seconds for employees" in a bathroom or food instructions at a burger king. It doesn't hurt if they know it and helps make sure they got everything.

FreeResponse: I think that it's appropriate because then a doctor can see it while he's performing the procedure. Additionally, I think it's appropriate because then other people can see it and know the risks as well. So it really helps both parties, although I think some people might get nervous to see it.
I think if it will help them remember and save lives it's a very good idea. They shouldn't have to be reminded of the safety procedures, but it would probably help some remember when in a rush.

I think seeing these precautions on the wall might help patients feel at ease knowing that their provider is concerned with safety. On the other hand, a doctor might not look at either depending on the complexity of the surgery.
You know, like, they gonna do what ever
The decision shouldn't have much impact on the patients health which is the most important fact. Regardless it should help to reduce the infections.
Even doctors are human and they can make mistakes.  It would be good to have the steps visible in case doctors need to look at them.  You can't be too cautious especially at a hospital.
The director is not a dr and should not dictate care decisions
It seems a bit controversial but he is the director so i would agree with his choice.
A dr shouldnt need constant reminder of a patients health and need directions to preform a proper procedure

Although it sounds like the director has good intentions it would likely go completely unused. I doubt a doctor is going to stop and read a list of instructions before doing a procedure they have probably done thousands of times before.
Either way it is safer than the previous way in which nothing was posted. This finds the best way
I think it might make the patient nervous

This intervention seems very appropriate, as it acts to remind the doctor without causing any other friction.  This study is OK as long as there is enough data to show the effectiveness of the procedure without the posters, otherwise there should also be a control group without the posters/badge instructions.
I think it is appropriate because people will think more of the director
The doctor should not experiment like this without running through a simulation that does not  include actual patient groups.  There must be informed consent.
Having notes readily available ensures fewer mistakes. Makes it easier for the doctors to memorize the steps.
Some doctors need reminders on safety procedures but they are too arrogant to receive direct instruction. This way they can read the poster and still pretend it doesn't apply to them.
It seems to be very important because it adds the info to their clothing so they can have the steps with them if needed.

Doctors are human and therefore make mistakes. These are not usually intentional, but any human error can be detrimental to the desired outcome. Therefore, having a checklist to constantly refer to is helpful and can help eliminate errors.

If the director truly doesn't know which one will reduce infections, then I think it's reasonable to try both.  This is a life-saving treatment that still needs to be administered so at least the director is trying to reduce the number of infections.
People should be able to identify the doctors.  Also, it is important for the doctor to remember the steps.  But, if he already knows the steps by heart it might now be necessary.
It's good to test these ideas out, but a year seems like a really long time with patients still being infected during this time.
I think it was a very appropriate decision because doctors can remember all the safety steps to take.That way there is less infections so less people get sick or die.
I don't see why it would be inappropriate. He is giving a reminder to all.
I think both methods can help prevent infection and this is a good meausre to see if steps are implemented
although it is somewhat demeaning to an MD, it can be useful. It may save a life.
This kind of thing is the directors job.  Who would be against saving lives? In fact, It would not be inappropriate for anyone with access to do this.

Rather than run an experiment where patients could potentially suffer, it seems more prudent to have the doctors take a required retraining course. Having posters and badges up to help remind doctors what to do is important, but it seems like it would be better to train them.
I think the posters will be a good helpful reminder.
These doctors should be trained well enough to not have to refer to a poster during a procedure.  The fact that they have to look at a poster is disturbing.
The safety procedures could help but it seems kind of bad to just stick people in rooms and test on them. What if these procedures don't help an the test subjects still get these deadly infections.

I think that it definitely wouldn't hurt to have the posters around and they might serve as a helpful reference. However, in practice I think that most doctors are unlikely to pay attention to the posters when they are busy with their day to day work.
I felt like the director's decision was very appropriate. He just wants to make sure all of the doctors follow directions and that is probably the best way to do it.
The director thinks that these posters might help doctors remember all of the safety steps they were trained to take during the procedure.
He doesn't know for sure if the poster and badges will help and he must figure out how to stop deadly infections.
His decision is appropriate because he is qualified to know what he's doing.

Yes it is good that they are showing doctors better ways to perform surgeries. They should not be showing them this information while undergoing a operation. They should instead talk to all the doctors who perform this operation before hand in a training session.
It will save the patients live.  It will also help people when they are sick in the future.
i think that the director should make it the same either way. you shouldn't make certain patients guinnea pigs.
How could it hurt? It's a good reminder of proper procedure and could save lives. It sounds like a great idea
Its just guidelines and some doctors might or not see it when performing the procedure. It would be better to do a training program so all doctors are aware.

Because the risk of infection is so high, and so high in general at hospitals. It's good for doctors to have the precautions readily available to them so that they can take the proper measures. Neither of these two methods are unethical, and may end up helping patients for the better.
I believe that the hospital director made a wise choice to run this test. Determining which is the better course could very well save patients lives in the future.
I think it is appropriate because it will help both patient and doctor to remember the procedure and allow them both to know about it in case  it is not done properly

Either of these options is better than providing no list of precautions at all, so all of the patients should be benefited. There shouldn't be a disadvantage to either option. One just might provide even more help than the other.
Given that the director apparently thinks such precautions are necessary, it would probably make sense to implement them throughout the hospital during a time frame much shorter than a year.
I think it's appropriate because both groups are being informed just in different ways.

To truly measure the effect of the badges and the posters, there needs to be a control group for which nothing changes (i.e., no new badge or poster). Also, the decision is only appropriate if there is some indication that the reason the infections are happening is because the doctors aren't following the standard safety precautions in the first place. If that is not the reason for the infections, then there's no reason to implement the new badges or posters.
It never hurts to be extra cautious.
If the infections are a big problem, this will help save lives. I think it's a great idea.
Experimenting with new policies is fine. But the experiment could cost someone their life. Seems a little wrong to me.
I think that this information could be reinforcing and helpful. Ultimately, the director's decision will be useful.
hanging up a poster is NOT going to change a thing, other than covering up a unsightly stain on the wall
It seems like an okay thing to do.  Nothing wrong with a friendly reminder.
I think it is good as a reminder but it wouldn't make me feel great knowing the doctors don't know proper safety procedures off hand and need to rely on am id card.

I think this is very inappropriate because it would lead to undue stress for the patient.  I think the risks should be explained to the patients [and apparently the doctors] in private so that the patients can make an informed decision.
It reminds the Dr how the procedure is done, it is up to the doctor to do it right.
Since infections are fairly common and can be fatal something needs to be done to prevent them. I do feel that posters on the wall of a patients room might be fairly alarming to the patient.
I think it's inappropriate because having something to remind you to perform on someone's life sounds ridiculous.  It will make the patient lose confidence in the doctor's ability.
I don't know how much it would help the doctors, but I don't think what he's doing is inappropriate. I think he's trying to help!
Is a good theory and test, I just feel bad for the 1/2 that doesn't do as well since doctors should all be relatively equal.
After a year, the director will check which option, badges or posters, is most effective, and make it standard for all patients and doctors throughout the entire hospital.
I feel like if such a simple steps will keep things safer, then that makes the most sense to me. I agree with his choice to split the patients up into 2 groups.
The doctor shouldn't be submitting patients to experiments that they haven't consented to.
given the likely infections the directors test to see which would be a better disclosure is appropriate. both sets are still getting disclosures via the doctor being reminded of procedures
It doesn't hurt anything.  THe signs don't put anyone at risk.  I'd like to believe that doctors don't need that sort of simplicity.

I don't think that comparing two groups differing in the location of the procedures is going to give the director any meaningful information.  He/she should compare doctors who take a certain precaution versus doctors who don't.
I feel like both are appropriate since they both include the safety steps, but in different ways. I don't see any glaring issues with the experiment.

Since people seem to be getting infections it is a good idea to remind doctors of the steps of the procedure if it will help reduce but on the other hand there is no statement stating that doctors aren't following the right steps and that is what is truly causing the infections

I think it's a great idea. Even though doctors are highly trained in these procedures they are human, and quite capable of mistakes.  I think it would serve as a good reminder to make sure they are taking the time to ensure they are following all the necessary precautions.
I think that it could help the doctors remember the safety steps.  I also think that doctors should have mastered all of those steps prior to performing such treatments.
It doesn't seem sterile and its almost like giving the doctors training wheels
Everyone, no matter how skilled or intelligent, can at times need a remember for following protocols accurately

I think this is a good idea that has the possibility to help.  If the doctors and their procedure execution needs work the a reminder like this poster while they are working could have really good results.
The posters can't harm, only help.

It's a little bit appropriate in that not just the doctors but the patients might be able to see safety precautions posted but just posting on a wall or a badge does not guarantee that those precautions will be followed.  I did not see anything where it was required to actually look at the posters or even the badges.  It seems like a lazy decision on the director's part.
There is no downside from having the precautions nearby for the doctors, either on the badge or a poster.
it is not a realistic approach.

If the safety steps make the procedure more safe, everything should be done to make sure the doctors are familiar with them. It seems very likely the posters would help, and there is no cost or risk involved in implementing it.
This is an appropriate experiment because it's focus is to improve the quality of their procedures. If less patients end up with infections as a result of this study, then it is very necessary.
It will help the doctor be more aware. It could distract them a bit, but overall it will help awareness. Awareness will prevent more infenction possibly.
The director is just making sure everything is done properly and reduces instances where there could be infections.  The information is available to both groups, just in different forms.

I don't see a downside to this although I think a poster would be better than information on an idea badge; people don't really look at their own idea badges throughout the day.  This may decrease patient confidence if they feel their health professionals need reminded about simple procedures.

I've never heard of this before, but if there are too many deadly infections, then I say, why not try it? I assume other ideas are out there and maybe have been tried. I know I heard recently that doctors and anyone around patients needs to wash their hands constantly to cut down on infections.
I think he should just use both methods. I think it would be very dangerous to test these methods on patients.
The director thinks that these new badges might help doctors remember all of the safety steps they were trained to take during the procedure.
It seems like there's a better way to do this.

It does not seem inappropriate, but it seems useless. The doctor would have to remove and turn over their ID badge, and couple potentially end up losing their badge because it is no longer attached to them. Furthermore, if they needed to look up the proper procedure, they could use their phone or another guide to help them.
If the doctor isn't confident in practicing his medicine, then he has no business being a doctor.
He has done what he has to do to help these people.
If it helps a patient, than it was worth it. Patients will also be able to see it and watch their doctor and question how things are done. I could see some doctors not liking this.
It might make some patients nervous. I also think that the benefits outweigh the downsides and if it prevents infections, it's worth it.
I think that the director isn't impacting safety too much, so his choices make sense and are appropriate for the situation. I'm sure there is more probably a better way to handle this though.

I would find it very unsettling that my doctor would need to check badges and posters on walls to remind himself of what procedures are appropriate when examining me or deciding to do a procedure that could cause me infection. I find the directors vision and his idea to mean well, but it just seems very inappropriate to me for the patients.
The steps need to be taken to minimize risk for infection.  These signs will serve as good reminders.
It may not stop all the infections, but there is no downside. If it stops 1 infection for 0 cost then it was a good choice.
The two experiments were appropriate because it can reduce the risks with both ways.
I feel the standards should be the same for all. They could have both. Human lives should not be used for testing.
I think it's a good idea. It never hurts to have reminders about things.

The director is giving both groups of doctors a reminder of the safety steps that need to be followed.  Which works better is probably specific to the individual doctors.  Trying to improve safety seems like a good goal

It seems like a good way to test the efficacy of the safety methods. I don't really see much wrong with it, other than the fact that maybe some patients could be harmed if one of the methods doesn't work as well. But then again, I don't see how having this information relayed to the doctors would make the risk of infection increase.
I don't think the idea is inappropriate. However, it is scary to think a doctor would need to look at a poster in order to do a simple procedure correctly.

This seems like a very good idea.  My primary concern would be that patients would think the doctor was not qualified, but even then, it rings similarly to posters that remind us how to wash our hands being placed in restrooms.
Because it would help the doctors to remember a task that they were trained to follow that they might forgot if they did not have a reminder.

The director is trying to limit the occurrences of deadly infections so any action toward that goal is appropriate. His actions are somewhat passive in just listing the safety procedures may not be enough to stop the occurrences (not to mention, I would assume the doctors already know and understand the safety procedures, so reminding them may not be necessary).
I think it could be a good idea. At the very least it will give doctors no excuse for knowing how to administer the tube.
It couldn't hurt. It might help doctors who forget the appropriate procedures or just want to make sure they're doing everything right.
It's a great idea.  Doctors are so busy and have to remember so much, there is nothing wrong with an ID with a reminder of proper safety precautions on the back.

I guess that that is certainly appropriate to do.  It can't hurt to remind them.  Frankly though, I think it would be wiser to just assign someone to be the safety officer.  It would be their job to check off the various safety precautions.
Information is power.  The posters may help.
The director should trust that his doctors are professionals.  The list of procedures might be insulting to the trained doctors on staff.
I think everyone has a right to access the information in the same way. It should be shared consistently and perhaps via both methods to ensure that everyone is given the same opportunity.
The doctor is being proactive.
I think this is appropriate because doctor's will then always have the procedure right on their person.   This will eliminate any chance of the doctors not knowing what the procedures are.
I would think the doctors should already be trained and have those procedures down pat before becoming a doctor
The director is justified in trying to reduce infections by innovative means.  However, if he thinks both the poster and the badge  will help doctors then he could just use both for all patients.
Anything is worth trying to help people.  It is inexpensive, but it may help be effective.

It's not a proper experiment. There's not a control group of doctors with no reminder of the safety precautions to ensure the result isn't random chance, noise, or the proficiency of individual doctors.

Doctor's can be dealing with many things at once and despite all their training they are only human and could possibly forget something in the heat of the situation.  Having a handy reminder tool can help to save lives.
Yes his idea can definitely bring about more awareness to the infection issue and how to avoid it.
Doctors should be familiar with basic safety precautions and the experiment should not affet patients' safety especially when information is available in both cases.

It's good he's trying to reduce infections but it seems a little wrong that maybe some people will have a larger chance of infection based on the method. It's good to test it out to see what works best though.

I don't understand how having the precautions written down could help the patients be safe from infections. One doesn't have anything to do with the other. And the doctors should already have this information memorized and learned without having to rely on written precautions.
It certainly makes sense to to provide doctors a reminder.
neither of these make sense. So there will be warning labels either on the doctor or the wall that say what, be careful?
Having information on hand never hurts and could give someone facts that they would have otherwise  forgotten.
I would hope that this solution works.

I think it's very appropriate because it will help avoid any mistakes during the procedure. If the  Doctors can look at the poster and go over the procedure before doing it, it is less likely that they could make a mistake that could result in a infection.
If it will reduce the number of infections then I think its a good idea.

I think the idea has the right premise in terms of having important information readily available. I find the exact form to be the problem. This is due to the fact that if this is a badge the doctor is wearing, they will have to touch it to be able to read it and that will not help their hands remain sterile. This could actually lead to more infections.
I think this would help new and old doctors. New doctors may not know the procedure as well as they could so the poster would help.
I don't know enough about the steps that are usually necessary to change procedures in a medical environment.
If the doctors can't remember how to keep it safe then they shouldn't be doing it this is why I have a problem with doctors because I don't think they are as smart as they say.
because he is the hospital director and its his job to do these things
The physican is attempting to raise awareness about these infections both passively with a new badge (easily ignored) and actively (in a specialized area with printed directions).

If the mere introduction of a poster can remind physicians to do more diligent work and remember safety procedures protocols, then the idea has much merit. Despite it being unorthodox, I say go with it.
It doesn't hurt to remind people of how to be careful
I think it's a reasonable theory, and certainly doesn't risk health. I do think, however, that there should be a control group.
I don't see anything wrong with it; I'd like to have easy access to how-to's when I'm working. It would make their work much easier.
I think the posters on the wall are a really great idea.  They would serve as a good reminder for the doctor, and he could go over them often.

Yes, I guess it is good to have the "safety steps" handy while the doctor's are doing this procedure (kind of like how a pilot keeps procedural steps strapped to his leg), but I would hope that it is unnecessary at this point in the doctors' careers.  Maybe Medical Schools should do this?
I think it isn't a bad idea and would only help in performing all standard safety precautions.  The doctors performing the procedures could reference it if needed which seems like a great idea.
I think that it would be a great reference for doctors to refer to as they are only human and its a good idea to have the reminders up if they can prevent complications from this procedure.
It's insulting to the doctor's intelligence.
I would have no way of knowing what might be appropriate or inappropriate for this scenario.
Everyone has memory lapses from time to time and this would be a great way to curb them. A reminder of the proper procedure would increase the chances that it would be followed.
I'm sure doctors know the safety precautions, but an extra reminder does nothing to hurt or impede them. It's always a good idea to have more information.

A doctor should really know the procedure by memory if they're working on someone that placed their lives in their hands. It is still a good reminder to have a checklist just to make sure or minimize chance of infection, but it might be a distraction having to review the list constantly.

Since doctors have so much knowledge crammed into their head over a number of years, having something in their face to remember the little details is a great wake up call.  Everyone becomes complacient with their normal duties and are apt to miss steps unless reminded of them.
Anything to help the doctors would be great. A friendly reminder could help.
It might not make the procedure itself any safer, but it would ensure that the doctors would consistently follow procedure and minimize risk.
I am not sure what to think, hopefully all patients will  be safe.
Patient health should come above all else. It also give the patient the comfort of knowing what will be done and that it is being done correctly.
It's appropriate because there is obviously a concern for infection. It's troublesome that doctors don't remember standard safety precautions but if it helps that's good.
Seeing the poster all the time would help the doctors always remember the safety steps. So all in all I think it would be appropriate to hang these posters in those rooms.
Well, will the doctor be able to turn the badge around and read the instructions without contaminating his hands?
I think it couldn't hurt to have a friendly reminder here & there. Either way I think both options would be equally effective.
I think it is a good way for doctors to reference a new medical practice. I don't think it is any different than a doctor having to look something up on an ipad.
Perform safety actions are very important for doctors.
It helps the doctor who is performing  the surgery to be precautions . It also helps them to refresh any doubts they may have about what they are doing.

It would just be odd for a trained professional to be carrying these instructions mid-surgery. With that said, even though it's a bit inappropriate, if that would mean less people with infections, I wouldn't mind it.
I see nothing wrong with the directors decision.  If it saves a single life or prevents one infection it is worth it.
Knowingly giving another set of patients a different level of care is disgusting.
It is always good to have a reminder of the steps even if you have done it multiple times to make sure that all safety steps are done and the patient is at least risk.
I don't see any down side in having the safety steps readily available.  This way if there is any doubt, they can just check the badge immediately.

I am not sure how appropriate this is because while it would help us gain information about the effectiveness of the treatments, you are also risking some of the participants to potential infections that can be fatal.
This is an appropriate decision and great way to see which reminder works better for the doctors. The director is being proactive about patient care and I think that is great.
Even though they should be trained, it would be a great reminder. If it helps cut down infections it will be beneficial.
People's lives are on the line - this doesn't seem like the best way to run the experiment
I don't think its right to have these people be tested on like this. They should just had one idea that will work and fix that problem.
It doesn't seem like a very effective way to help the problem. And that means that there's a whole group of people that might not be getting the best safety and care.
It's a nice, basic reminder for the doctors.
better be safe than sorry

There are a million different things a doctor needs to remember . . . not sure why this particular procedure alone warrants instructions to carry around on an ID - which would be awkward to look at during the procedure anyway. They would likely forget it's even on there. Would be better to have the instructions printed on the bag of plastic tubing or something instead.
Seems like a guessing game not based on actual research.
This sounds like a great idea as a reminder to everyone to stay safe when doing the procedure. I feel like thats a really smart way to prevent infections.
He is not endangering anyone and he is finding out what is the best practice.
Depending on how crucial the procedure is-having a doctor stop to read instructions is kinda scary. Maybe the doctor wont have time

I think this is a decent idea to help doctors remember the steps and help prevent infections. The only issue I have is patients perhaps being off put by the poster hanging on the wall. They may think the doctor does not fully know what they are doing.

I would expect a qualified surgeon to be able to perform the procedure without looking at a safety poster. Although the director's intentions may be well meaning, he is not presenting a professional manner to the hospital.
i think it made sense to me.

The badge would not be sanitary and would require the doctor to stop and check it. It would be better to have a poster of the procedures in the operating room and have the assistant also be responsible for following the procedures.
I think this is a small yet effective approach to solving this problem. I feel like we all need reminders in our daily lives

I think doctors should memorize all the safety steps and be able to perform the procedure without looking at the list. I'm not sure if all the doctors would actually look at the list while performing the procedure.
Reminding the doctors of the correct procedure is good because they're working under pressure and might forget small, important details.
Everyone should get the besttreatment. The doctors should have both a poster and a card.

WHile I think that it is kind of careless not to make sure they are implemented to all. I think it is still an effort to make sure people know and learn them. So if it helps to identify a way to make it be a standard then whatever works.
Neither option in this experiment causes any known harm to anyone. Learning which option is more effective may help many patients in the long run.
The posters will teach people how to be safe
The poster hanging is appropriate.  I'm not if the doctor's will actually use it though.   They should have more training instead of looking at a guideline poster in front of a patient.
A practicing doctor should not run experiments on his patients, this should be research work.
If a procedure requires a doctor to do it he or she should not need to look at a badge or poster to know how to do their job. That is the reason they went to medical school.
The director recognizes that there is a potentially deadly risk involved with some of the medical procedures and is taking action to minimize the risk of infection.
it's appropriate but I doubt if the doctor is going to be reading the back of the badge before or while doing the procedure....

I think anything that would help cut down on the infection risk is good . So , if doctors had these instructions on them at all times , it would probably help reduce the chance of an infection happening.

I think anything that can help doctors, even subconsciously if they just glance past the poster, can help them better serve their patients.  Infections can be bad so making sure everyone involved is informed on how to prevent and treat them is good management in my opinion.
Patients should be given the same standard of care, not being unwitting subjects of an experiment. Test it in a controlled environment.
I think it is a simple and effective way to save people's lives.
Seems a little extreme.
it would help doctors to have the list of safety procedures on them at all times to consult when they need
i think its interesting but concerned about the protocol and whetehr it is needlessly endangerig some patients
The director's decision is proactive and will assist doctor's in taking the steps to prevent infections. Doctors do not always do things correctly, so this is helpful.

The doctors went to medical school,internships, and residencies. They should know the procedures by heart. Having posters on the wall with the instructions and on their badges, damage their credibility in the eyes of the patients. Plus, I don't think the doctors would be too happy with the administrator for pushing these ideas on them.
Degree_spec: Radiologic Technology, Ultrasound Technology, BS in Healthcare Management

FreeResponse: I think that if you're going to give the hints, you should probably do it for everybody.
I think it's an excellent idea for them to have safety procedures printed so closely. It would probably help to eliminate a lot of problems that could come up.
There is no incentive for them to look at the badge to read the procedures. Most people don't really pay attention to badges while they are wearing them.
Any measure that can help patients receive better care is a welcome addition to a hospital. Anything should be considered if it means saving lives and suffering for patients.
I think it is appropriate because if a new doctor is performing this procedure then a little reminder could not hurt anything. It would serve simply as extra help if needed.
Both the poster and the badge would really help the doctor and remind him or her of what to do. That's all I have to say, honestly.
It's a good check list to help Drs. remember. Assuming the read it before every procedure. It may jog their memory about a step they may have otherwise forgotten.
The director is trying to give doctors a handy checklist to make sure they follow the proper procedures.

I feel that the doctors should already be well aware of the safety precautions if they are to treat patients with a device that could potentially lead to infections. If they need a list to look over proper safety precautions, they're not fit to perform the procedure. Also, adding a list like this will only serve to distract the doctor and hinder him rather than help.
It gives the guidance. The doctors will have to obey the rules. There are no excuses
I think this could be a good idea so patients know exactly what are the negative consequences that could derive from this procedure.
with the list of standard safety precautions on the back this be beneficial for the doctors help prevent infections
I don't think a doctor will have the time nor remember that these procedures are printed on the ID Badge.  Seems as if they should already know how to do this.
it saves lives
I would think that this could be helpful. However, that is with only the provided detail in mind. Additional information could impact how this idea is perceived.
Safety first - having the directions would be good for the doctor who might forget the directions.
It'll be a good reminder for doctors. However, over time they'll get used to it being there and stop referencing it.
It is unclear as to whether doctors would use this just because it's available. However, if safety mistakes are being made, then it's appropriate.
It shows that they are qualified.
Couldn't hurt. Might help.
Having instructions for a common procedure always available is not a bad idea.

The director wants to maximize the chances that doctors will remember the safety steps and have them in mind. He proposes something that is intuitive and easy to implement. Even if the attempt through this procedure is not sufficiently effective, the attempt takes so very few resources and little effort that it is worth the try.
They should remember the procedure before entering the rooms
It doesn't affect anything one way or the other really.
it seems okay and it wouldnt be too risky

I mean it is a good idea, however it is kind of distracting as well as ..time consuming. These workers need to be more educated and well trained as well as skilled. If they are not quite there yet, and are hesitant, then it absolutely unsafe for them to proceed with the procedure.
I think it could hurt some patients
I feel the director was not out of line..
It will be reminder that they hold someone's life in their hands.
I think it does no harm and helps to promote safe behavior
I think this would be a helpful and useful reminder of what safety precautions should be followed.
Every medical procedure has risks. I respect the effort made in order to reduce them.
It is always good to find and implement ways to keep safety in focus
He is helping educate the fellow doctors.
i think tis a good idea. it will keep it fresh in their memories

The experiment doesn't have a control group that isn't using either of the new ideas.  He needs a control group to be able to see if the procedures actually help.  Also, depending on what precisely the doctor wishes to measure with the other two groups, there may be competing influences.  For example, if the group with the doctor with the ID badge has far fewer infections, one can't be sure that it was because of the ID badge, or that he even read the instructions on it.
It is good that the patients and doctors know all the risks
I feel like by giving the doctors access to the safety precautions while they are working is a great way to give them the information they need to complete a safe and effective procedure.

I think that putting a poster on the wall with information that should already be known by the doctor is not right. It will lead the patient to think they are incompetent. The badge is a better idea but overall I think a doctor should know how to treat patients well enough without a "cheat sheet" essentially.
I just feel like the better option would be to have training so they actually learn the technique. I don't think many doctors will stop and take the time to look at their badge or read a poster.
Doctors are professionals they shouldn't need these reminders. Should they need the reminders I would consider them incompetent.
I feel there is a good reason for this, so that is all.

I think it's good that the hospital director is trying to implement ways to decrease the rates of these infections. Experiments can be expensive to carry out.  Assuming this is not the case with this experiment, I think it's a good idea.  If it's not dangerous or costly to run an experiment, more experimenting is probably better.
is good idea

The safety concerns for such this type of medical procedure cannot be understated. Infections during hospital treatments are a major concern of physicians, and having the standard safety precautions readily available as a reminder is important.

Instead of having badges and posters that could distract doctors, they should all be required to pass regular tests and make sure they are completely sure about how to execute this process, before doing it to actual patients. They should be supervised by more experienced doctors until they are ready to do it on their own.
It is inappropriate because the patients are being used as unwitting test subjects.  They have no choice but to "participate" in this "experiment".
I feel that it goes against ethical standards.  I think it may lead to potential issues.
good
I am a little afraid it might kill someone from an infections but I think saving lives and waiting for the results would give people more hope

I think it is somewhat appropriate because the director is not putting anyone to additional risk and may provide a better way to prevent infections that may be caused by the procedure.  Not completely certain this is ethical however as he is using human beings as experiment subjects without their or their providers knowledge

As long as the doctors pay attention to where the recommended treatments are written, the patients should be fine. The respective doctors just need to remember whether or not the recommended treatments are written on their badges or on posters.
